G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, because this is a Complaint for Modification of an existing custody and parenting time judgment of the Middlesex Probate and Family Court, and both parties and the Children reside within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, because this is a Complaint for Modification of an existing custody and parenting time judgment of the Middlesex Probate and Family Court, and both parties and the Children reside within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, because this is a Complaint for Modification of an existing custody and parenting time judgment of the Middlesex Probate and Family Court, and both parties and the Children reside within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The duty of the Court to safeguard the welfare of minor children is further grounded in G.L. c. 208, § 31, which provides that custody determinations shall be made “in accordance with the best interests of the child” and directs the Court to consider, among other factors, the child’s relationship with each parent, the child’s adjustment to home and community, and the ability of each parent to provide for the child’s needs.

*M.C. v. T.K.*, 463 Mass. 226, 231\u2013.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, “[a] judgment for custody of minor children may be modified when the moving party shows that a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred and that the modification is in the best interests of the child[ren].” *M.C. v. T.K.*, 463 Mass. 226, 231–232 (2012); see also G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20.
*M.C. v. T.K.*, 463 Mass. 226, 231\u2013.support_reasoning: The opinion text provided focuses on initial child support setting between never-married parents with shared physical custody and high incomes. It does not address modification of an existing custody judgment, nor does it articulate any standard about a “material and substantial change in circumstances” or tie that to the best interests of the children as a prerequisite for modifying custody. Therefore, the case, at least in the excerpt given, does not support the specific modification standard stated in the proposition.
*M.C. v. T.K.*, 463 Mass. 226, 231\u2013.relevant_excerpt: On remand, the judge is not required to revisit the issue of the father’s income at the time of trial, but should consider whether the circumstances have materially changed since the date of the judgment before us, and should base any award of child support on the parties’ current incomes.

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u2.proposition: In determining whether to modify custody or parenting time, the Court’s “paramount concern” is the “best interests of the child.” *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 840–842 (2003); *Adoption of Vito*, 431 Mass. 550, 566–567 (2000).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses the ‘best interests of the child’ standard as the controlling principle in custody determinations and quotes prior Massachusetts precedent stating that the children’s best interests are the ‘paramount concern.’ Although the case is about an initial custody determination rather than a later modification, the reasoning broadly reaffirms that custody decisions turn on the child’s best interests and cites Yannas and similar authorities using that ‘paramount’ language. Thus it provides solid support for the proposition that the court’s paramount concern in custody/parenting time determinations is the child’s best interests.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u2.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 657 (2002)…; Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

*Adoption of Vito*, 431 Mass. 550, 566\u.proposition: In determining whether to modify custody or parenting time, the Court’s “paramount concern” is the “best interests of the child.” *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 840–842 (2003); *Adoption of Vito*, 431 Mass. 550, 566–567 (2000).
*Adoption of Vito*, 431 Mass. 550, 566\u.support_reasoning: The decision is an adoption/termination case rather than a custody or parenting-time modification case, but the court repeatedly frames its authority and analysis in terms of acting in the child’s "best interests" and describes that standard as paramount in children’s matters. The opinion explicitly states that the Probate Court’s equitable powers are exercised to afford relief "in the best interests" of the child and later notes that "our jurisprudence has always made the interest of the child paramount," which aligns with the proposition, though in an adjacent (adoption/visitation) rather than pure custody-modification context.
*Adoption of Vito*, 431 Mass. 550, 566\u.relevant_excerpt: Each day judges must grapple with the consequences of significant relationships that develop between young children and the adults in whose care or custody they are placed. It is for that reason that our jurisprudence has always made the interest of the child paramount. Richards v. Forrest, 278 Mass. 547, 553 (1932).

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595\.proposition: The best‑interests analysis focuses on the particular needs of the children and the ability of each parent to meet those needs, including stability, safety, and the quality of the child’s home environment and relationships.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595\.support_reasoning: The opinion does engage in a best‑interests analysis, but the quoted portion focuses almost entirely on the need to make explicit findings about domestic violence and its effects on the child, not on a generalized standard that custody decisions must evaluate each child’s particular needs and each parent’s ability to provide stability, safety, and an appropriate home environment and relationships. The court describes specific factors in this case (e.g., domestic violence, child’s bond with father, school performance) but does not articulate the broader, multi‑factor best‑interests formulation stated in the proposition. Thus, the case only indirectly reflects those ideas and does not clearly establish the claimed principle as a rule of law.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595\.relevant_excerpt: “He evaluated the family with a focus on the particular circumstances of this case and the needs of this child at this time. … The judge was also moved by the fact that the boy appeared to be doing very well in his school work and that the father takes a great interest in his activities, meeting regularly with the boy’s teachers. Finally, the Probate Court judge noted that the father, who had been a heavy drinker, had not used alcohol since 1985 and attends weekly sessions of Alcoholics Anonymous.”

*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366, 370.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that changed work schedules, chronic inability to exercise parenting time as ordered, and instability in the children’s routine can constitute a material change in circumstances justifying modification of an existing custody or parenting schedule.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366, 370.support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with modification of alimony and child support based on the payor’s financial circumstances (income, earning capacity, and assets). It does not involve custody, parenting time, work schedules, or instability in children’s routines, nor does it articulate any standard for when such parenting-related changes constitute a material change in circumstances. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition about modifying custody or parenting schedules based on changed work schedules or parenting-time instability.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366, 370.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. … In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. … A substantial and permanent decrease in the income of the support provider is one of the material circumstances to be considered in a request for reduction of a support reward.”

*Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182, 19.proposition: Where the existing parenting plan is no longer workable in light of a parent’s changed schedule, and where the de facto arrangements differ from the written order, the Court may modify the order to conform to the child’s best interests and the actual circumstances.
*Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182, 19.support_reasoning: The case does involve a judgment of modification, but it does not discuss modification of a parenting plan or visitation schedule due to a parent’s changed schedule or a de facto arrangement differing from the written order. The only custody-related issue is the shift from shared to sole legal custody, which is vacated for lack of findings about best interests, and there is no mention of existing parenting plans becoming unworkable or modifying orders to conform to actual de facto arrangements. Thus, the opinion does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
*Rosenberg v. Merida*, 428 Mass. 182, 19.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’… However, the judge ‘failed to make specific or detailed findings…’ We vacate the judgment insofar as it awards sole legal custody to the defendant, and remand for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.”

*Cooper v. Keto*, 83 Mass. App. Ct. 798,.proposition: Where the existing parenting plan is no longer workable in light of a parent’s changed schedule, and where the de facto arrangements differ from the written order, the Court may modify the order to conform to the child’s best interests and the actual circumstances.
*Cooper v. Keto*, 83 Mass. App. Ct. 798,.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a brief concurrence focused solely on the disproportionate cost of litigation and a general admonition that litigation should be a last resort. It does not address parenting plans, changed parental schedules, de facto vs. written custodial arrangements, or standards for modification based on the child’s best interests. Therefore, this text does not provide authority for the proposition claimed.
*Cooper v. Keto*, 83 Mass. App. Ct. 798,.relevant_excerpt: "Here, we again witness another puzzling situation in which the legal fees paid and awarded far exceed any amount that would be gained.… Litigation should be the last option, not the first.… In devising the judicial playbook, one should not forget the pocketbook."

*Custody of Zia*, 455 Mass. 327, 333\u20.proposition: The Court may also consider whether a parent is relying on third parties to provide primary care during his or her parenting time, and whether such arrangements promote or impair the children’s welfare and stability.
*Custody of Zia*, 455 Mass. 327, 333\u20.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal homicide and post‑conviction review case, not a child custody or parenting‑time case. The court’s discussion focuses on evidentiary, investigatory, and prosecutorial issues and nowhere addresses how a court should evaluate a parent’s reliance on third parties for primary care of children or the impact of such arrangements on children’s welfare and stability. The cited pages do not concern custody or parental caregiving arrangements at all, so the case does not support the stated proposition.
